document_content.title: Referral to General Medicine for Evaluation of Persistent Fatigue

sections.heading: Reason for Referral
sections.content: Jane Doe is being referred for further evaluation of persistent fatigue and intermittent low-grade fevers that have not resolved despite initial outpatient management. She requires a comprehensive medical assessment to rule out underlying systemic causes.

sections.heading: History of Present Illness
sections.content: Ms. Doe reports experiencing generalized fatigue for the past three months, accompanied by occasional low-grade fevers (up to 37.8Â°C) and mild myalgias. She denies any significant weight loss, night sweats, or recent travel. There is no history of chronic illness, and she has not noticed any new rashes, joint swelling, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Over-the-counter analgesics have provided minimal relief.

sections.heading: Relevant Medical History
sections.content: No known chronic illnesses. No prior hospitalizations or surgeries. Family history is unremarkable for autoimmune or malignant conditions. She does not smoke and drinks alcohol socially.

sections.heading: Medications and Allergies
sections.content: Currently taking a daily multivitamin. No known drug allergies.

sections.heading: Examination Findings
sections.content: Vital signs are stable. Mild pallor noted on examination. No lymphadenopathy or organomegaly appreciated. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable.

sections.heading: Assessment
sections.content: 35-year-old female with persistent fatigue and intermittent low-grade fevers of unclear etiology. Differential diagnosis includes viral infection, early connective tissue disease, or hematologic disorder.

sections.heading: Plan
sections.content: Referral to General Medicine for further evaluation. Recommend laboratory workup including CBC, ESR, CRP, thyroid function tests, and basic metabolic panel. Consider infectious and autoimmune screening as indicated. Patient advised to monitor symptoms and return if condition worsens.
